qas.question: How claims to have stolen the FA cup?

answers.text: 80 year old career criminal Henry (Harry) James Burge claimed to have committed the theft
He claimed to have carried out the robbery with two other men

qas.question: How long go did this crime take place?
What did Burge do with the cup?

answers.text: the cup had been melted down to make counterfeit half-crown coins

qas.question: What did they do with those coins?

answers.text: stolen silver was being used to forge coins which were then laundered through betting shops at a local racecourse

qas.question: When did Henry James Burge commit the theft?
When did the Birmingham Post publish its report?

plausible_answers.text: his account of the means of entry and other items stolen

qas.question: What made detectives decide there was a possibility of conviction?
What crime did Burge commit that he spent 42 years in prison for?

context: Almost <a2_0>60 years<a2_0/> later, <a0_0>80 year old career criminal <b5_0>Henry (Harry) James Burge<b5_0/> claimed to have committed the theft<a0_0/>, confessing to a newspaper, with the story being published in the Sunday Pictorial newspaper on <b6_0><b7_0>23 February 1958<b7_0/><b6_0/>. <a1_0>He claimed to have carried out the robbery with two other men<a1_0/>, although when discrepancies with a contemporaneous report in the Birmingham Post newspaper (the crime pre-dated written police reports) in <b8_0>his account of the means of entry and other items stolen<b8_0/>, detectives decided there was no realistic possibility of a conviction and the case was closed. Burge claimed <a3_0>the cup had been melted down to make counterfeit half-crown coins<a3_0/>, which matched known intelligence of the time, in which <a4_0>stolen silver was being used to forge coins which were then laundered through betting shops at a local racecourse<a4_0/>, although Burge had no past history of <b9_0>forgery<b9_0/> in a record of 42 previous convictions for which he had spent 42 years in prison. He had been further imprisoned in 1957 for seven years for theft from cars. Released in 1961, he died in 1964.
